abstract: Killings of coalition service members in Afghanistan heighten worries about how the coalition troops, who are training members of the Afghan Army and the police, can protect themselves while working so closely with their Afghan counterparts; Afghan and NATO officials say they are examining the extent to which the attacks by Afghans in positions of trust are part of a concerted Taliban strategy to disrupt the coalition’s operations.

byline.contributor: Sangar Rahimi contributed reporting from Kabul, and an employee of The New York Times from Helmand Province, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: The killings heightened worries about how the coalition troops can protect themselves while working at close quarters with their Afghan counterparts.

headline.main: Coalition Soldiers Killed Were Shot in Company of Afghans
headline.print_headline: As Afghans Kill Allies, Force’s Trust Is Shaken
